title: AI Policy Updates
author: Linda Williams-Brown
content:
Major AI Policy Developments Shaping the Future

As artificial intelligence (AI) continues to evolve at a rapid pace, governments and organizations worldwide are enacting policies to manage its development and deployment responsibly. This article explores some of the most significant AI policy updates reported up to April 2024, highlighting their impact on various sectors and the broader implications for society.

Biden-Harris Administration's Executive Order

One of the most impactful policy developments in the United States has been the Biden-Harris administration's comprehensive Executive Order on AI, announced in late 2023. This order mandates federal agencies to address the safety and security risks associated with AI, including the potential misuse of AI in creating dangerous biological materials. Agencies have established frameworks for nucleic acid synthesis screening and released draft documents on managing generative AI risks. These efforts aim to prevent the misuse of AI and ensure its secure development and deployment across critical infrastructure sectors.

The administration has also focused on mitigating risks to workers, consumers, and civil rights. The Department of Labor (DOL) has developed guidelines to help federal contractors comply with worker protection laws when deploying AI in the workplace, promoting equal employment opportunities and mitigating the potentially harmful impacts of AI on employment decisions.

Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Guidance

In March 2024, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) issued its first government-wide AI policy, providing guidance on governance and risk management for federal agencies using AI. This policy emphasizes the importance of safe, secure, and trustworthy AI applications, setting a precedent for how AI should be integrated into government operations. The OMB guidance is part of a broader effort to ensure that AI technologies are used responsibly and ethically in public administration.

USPTO Guidance on AI and Intellectual Property

The United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) has issued new guidance concerning the use of AI tools by parties and practitioners. This guidance aims to address the challenges posed by AI in intellectual property law, ensuring that AI-generated innovations are adequately protected and regulated. The USPTO's efforts are crucial for fostering innovation while maintaining a fair and transparent intellectual property system.

European Union's AI Act

In Europe, the AI Act proposed by the European Union (EU) represents one of the most comprehensive regulatory frameworks for AI to date. The AI Act classifies AI systems based on their risk levels and imposes stringent requirements on high-risk AI applications. This legislation aims to ensure that AI technologies are safe, transparent, and respect fundamental rights. By setting clear standards, the AI Act seeks to create a trustworthy environment for AI innovation in the EU.

AI Labelling Policies by Major Platforms

Major technology platforms like YouTube, Meta, and TikTok have introduced policies to label AI-generated content, addressing concerns about misinformation and the authenticity of online media. YouTube's new tool requires creators to disclose when content includes altered or synthetic media, while Meta has expanded its labelling of AI-generated images and videos to include more context on high-risk content. TikTok has adopted a proactive approach, labelling AI-generated content uploaded from other platforms to enhance transparency.

These policies are part of a broader trend towards greater accountability and transparency in the digital space, ensuring that users can trust the information they encounter online. By labelling AI-generated content, these platforms aim to mitigate the spread of misinformation and provide users with the context needed to make informed decisions.

Impact and Future Directions

The recent policy updates highlight the growing recognition of the need for robust AI governance frameworks. As AI technologies become increasingly integrated into various aspects of society, these policies will play a crucial role in ensuring their responsible and ethical use. From safeguarding civil rights to enhancing transparency in digital media, these regulatory efforts are shaping the future of AI in meaningful ways.

Looking ahead, it is essential for policymakers, industry leaders, and stakeholders to continue collaborating on developing and refining AI policies. By addressing the challenges and opportunities presented by AI, we can harness its potential for good while minimizing risks and ensuring that AI benefits all members of society.
